College of Energy, Xiamen University Xiamen Fujian 361102 PR China. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Several Rh-based La2Zr2O7 type catalysts promoted by the transition metals (Mn, Fe, and Co respectively) were synthesized and used to reform n-hexadecane (a diesel surrogate) that contains 50 ppm dibenzothiophene for hydrogen production. Compared to Co-LaZrRh and Mn-LaZrRh, the Fe-LaZrRh catalyst exhibited the best hydrogen extraction capability and sulfur tolerance. This is probably due to the introduction of Fe, which not only enhances the Rh dispersion, but also facilitates the formation of electron-deficient Rh sites and the generation of oxygen vacancies. Additionally, electron-deficient Rh sites can hinder the formation of an irreversible sulfur-metal bond, thus resulting in better sulfur tolerance and thermal stability. Finally, the generated oxygen vacancies may also activate steam to form surface active oxygen species, which help remove the deposited carbon on the catalyst surface. In summary, the developed Fe-LaZrRh catalyst performed the best in the steam reforming of n-hexadecane containing 50 ppm sulfur, which deserves further exploration for future applications. Graphical Abstract Illustration of the catalyst structure and its performance in diesel reforming. ga1 Keywords Diesel reforming Rh catalyst Pyrochlore of La2Zr2O7 Metal substitution Sulfur tolerance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The shortage of fossil fuels and the advent of global warming are driving a growing demand for sustainable and environmentally-friendly energies. As a clean and environmentally benign energy carrier, hydrogen, over the past several years has emerged as a possible alternative to fossil fuels [1]. At the same time, the hydrogen fuel cell has received much attention due to its higher efficiency, cleanliness, and quietness [2]. However, as it is difficult to store and transport hydrogen because of its low density, the extended usage of hydrogen as a fuel has been very limited [3]. To resolve this problem, steam reforming of hydrocarbons that have ready infrastructures for on-site or on-board production of hydrogen could be a good solution [4–8]. This is especially true for diesel, as it is a logistic fuel that contains rich hydrogen with higher volumetric and gravimetric energy densities. In addition, it is well known that diesel, as a liquid fuel, is easy to store and transport because of its ready infrastructure and accessibility [5,9,10]. Hence, the steam reforming of diesel (SRD) could be a convenient way for extracting H2, which involves an endothermic reaction represented by Eq. (1) below [11]. However, the complex composition of diesel, that contains organic sulfur impurities, is not conducive to the reforming process. Organic sulfur can be converted into H2S species at high temperatures with H2, which could attach onto the active metal surface to form irreversible sulfur-metal bonds, leading to catalyst poisoning. Moreover, the presence of organic sulfur impurities accelerates the carbon deposited on the surface of active metals, causing a severe deactivation of catalysts [12]. Therefore, an appropriate catalyst with better resistance to sulfur and carbon deposition is imperative for the long-term operation of diesel reforming. (1) C m H n + m H 2 O → 1 2 n + m H 2 + m CO Δ H > 0 For many years, Ni, as an active metal, has been widely used in reforming hydrocarbon fuels due to its low cost [13–19]. However, for heavy-hydrocarbon fuels like diesel, Ni is prone to both serious deactivation via sintering and sulfur poisoning due to the high organic sulfur contained in the fuel [20–22], thus making the catalysts incapable of being used for long-term operation in the reforming of heavy-hydrocarbons. Precious metal catalysts [9,23–26], especially Rh based, are reported to be good catalysts, as they can significantly alleviate deactivation when used for reforming heavy-hydrocarbon fuels due to their tolerance to carbon deposition and sulfur poisoning. Xie et al. [27] compared the catalytic performance of Rh/CeO2-Al2O3 and Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 in reforming Norpar13 with 3-methylbenzothiophene. The experimental results showed that Ni/CeO2-Al2O3 lost its catalytic performance quickly, while Rh/CeO2-Al2O3 maintained a higher catalytic activity and sulfur tolerance. Shoynkhorova et al. [9] investigated a series of Rh, Pt, Ru/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2-δ catalysts used in diesel reforming. The results showed that Rh/Ce0.75Zr0.25O2-δ presented the best activity and stability. On the other hand, the supporting oxides also had a significant effect on the catalytic performance during the reforming process. The strong metal-support interactions resulted in highly dispersed Rh particles, allowing more metal sites to be exposed on the catalyst surface, which were able to effectively improve the reforming performance of catalysts and their tolerance to sulfur poisoning and carbon deposition [28]. Xie et al. [24] prepared a series of Rh supported on different oxide catalysts, such as Al2O3 and CeO2, to investigate the effect of supporting oxides on sulfur resistance in steam reforming of Norpar 13. The test results showed that Rh/Al2O3 presented the highest catalytic activity when used for extracting H2 from Norpar 13. The results also indicated that the strong interactions between Rh and Al2O3 were able to effectively anchor Rh particles to the oxides, preventing Rh particles from aggregating. More importantly, the interaction could result in the formation of electron-deficient Rh particles on Al2O3 due to the transfer of electrons from Rh to Al2O3, which weakened the sulfur adsorbed onto the catalyst, thus alleviated the formation of Rh-S bond and enhanced the sulfur resistance. Additionally, the sulfur K-edge XANES verified that the main sulfur species on the spent Rh/Al2O3 were sulfonate and sulfate rather than sulfide. Compared to the traditional method of supporting Rh on the surface of oxides (such as Al2O3, CeO2, and SiO2 etc.), embedding active metals into the lattice of the complex oxides, such as spinel oxide-AB2O4 [6,29], perovskite oxide-ABO3 [30,31], and pyrochlore oxide-A2B2O7 [32,33] could achieve higher dispersion of the active metals because of their strong anchoring effect to stabilize the structure. Recently, La2Zr2O7, a finely engineered pyrochlore mixed oxide, was tested as a promising catalyst precursor material to extract H2 from hydrocarbons because of its unique features like high thermal stability at high temperatures and excellent redox properties [34,35]. A few studies have also indicated that partial substitution of Zr in La2Zr2O7 by Rh exhibited a positive impact on the catalytic performance and sulfur resistance during hydrocarbon reforming. For instance, Haynes et al. [36] used Sr and Rh to partially substitute La and Zr in the La2Zr2O7 pyrochlore structure and synthesized a catalyst of La1.5Sr0.5Zr1.9Rh0.1O7-δ for the partial oxidation of n-tetradecane, which contained 1000 ppm dibenzothiophene, and compared its catalytic reforming performance to that of a commercial catalyst Rh/γ-Al2O3 in reforming n-tetradecane. The results indicated that strongly bound and well dispersed Rh particles were formed in the La1.5Sr0.5Zr1.9Rh0.1O7-δ, leading to better catalytic performance and higher tolerance to sulfur poisoning than Rh/γ-Al2O3. In addition, the physicochemical features of pyrochlore La2Zr2O7 were able to be controlled flexibly through the partial substitution of A- and/or B-sites, so that oxygen vacancies concentration, which contributes to the migration of oxygen ions in pyrochlore La2Zr2O7, can be enriched by the partial substitution of A- and/or B-sites, allowing the deposited carbon to be effectively boosted during the reforming process [37–39]. Haynes et al. [36] further verified that the Sr substitution into La-sites (A-sites) improved the oxygen ion mobility more for La1.5Sr0.5Zr1.9Rh0.1O7-δ than for La2Zr1.9Rh0.1O7-δ. Bhattar et al. [21] also investigated the partial substitution of La-sites with Ca and Sr and synthesized La1.95Ca0.05Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-δ and La1.95Sr0.05Zr1.44Ni0.56O7-δ, which are used to reform methane individually. Their experimental results showed that the partial substitution of Ca and Sr improved the catalysts’ tolerance to carbon deposition. Inspired by Bhattar’s work, we used the transition metals (TMs), such as Mn, Fe, and Co as the promoted metals, which were used to partially replace the Zr-sites in pyrochlore La2Zr2O7 to tune its physicochemical properties with Rh still kept as the active metal. In addition, the impact of different TMs doping on the generation of oxygen vacancies, the electron-deficient sites of active metal Rh, and the catalytic activity in SRD was systematically investigated. As no studies focus on this topic of heavy-hydrocarbons reforming to date, it might be deserved having a try. In summary, a type of La2Zr1.89−yRh0.11TMyO7-δ catalyst was synthesized and investigated for its catalytic behavior for n-hexadecane with the presence of organic sulfur (as the surrogate of diesel). Numerous characterizations were carried out to obtain the insight into the relationship between catalytic performance and physicochemical properties. We hope this work could provide some theoretical basis for the future potential application of pyrochlore La2Zr2O7 as a catalyst in reforming heavy hydrocarbons for hydrogen production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Pyrochlore type catalysts, La2Zr1.89−yTMyRh0.11O7, were synthesized via the sol-gel method. Lanthanum nitrates hydrate (La(NO3)3·nH2O), zirconyl chloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2·8 H2O), manganese nitrate solution (Mn(NO3)2), cobaltous nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6 H2O), ammonium iron (II) sulfate (NH4)Fe(SO4)2·6 H2O, and rhodium nitrate (Rh(NO3)3) were used as the precursor materials. All reagents were used without further pretreatment. In a typical synthesis process, the stoichiometric amounts of La(NO3)3·nH2O, ZrOCl2·8 H2O, Rh(NO3)3 and TMs nitrate were dissolved in 5 ml of deionized water, and citric acid monohydrate (C6H8O7·H2O) was then added into the mixed solution (n(C6H8O7·H2O): n(Metaln+) = 1.2:1). The obtained solution was then heated at 65 °C for about 3 h until a viscous gel was formed. Subsequently, the gel was left in a drying oven at 130 °C for 2 h, and then calcined at 1000 °C for 4 h. After the above processing, the materials of La2Zr1.29Mn0.6Rh0.11O7-δ (Mn-LaZrRh), La2Zr1.3Fe0.59Rh0.11O7-δ (Fe-LaZrRh), and La2Zr1.32Co0.57Rh0.11O7-δ (Co-LaZrRh) were obtained. The weight percentage of the corresponding TMs was 6 wt.%. Additionally, La2Zr1.89Rh0.11O7-δ (LaZrRh) was synthesized via the same method but without TM nitrates used. A 2 wt.% of Rh content was used for all the prepared catalyst samples. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The pyrochlore structure of the prepared samples was verified using a Rigaku Ultima Ⅳ X-ray diffraction (XRD) diffractometer (λ = 1.5406 Å). The Raman vibration mode of the prepared samples was collected with a XploRA PLUS microscope spectrometer to obtain the metal-oxygen bonding information, and the detective laser wavelength (λ) was 532 nm. The morphology and crystal structure of the prepared catalyst samples were obtained with a FEI Tecnai G2 F20 Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM), while the elemental distribution was investigated using an energy dispersive spectroscope (EDS). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the prepared catalyst samples were detected on a Micrometrics ASAP 2020 analyzer at − 196 °C. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD), and H2 pulse chemisorption were carried out on a micrometrics AutoChem 2920 instrument and recorded by an on-line thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For H2-TPR analysis, about 0.1 g samples were heated at 300 °C for 1 h to remove the adsorbed impurities, and then cooled to 50 °C in pure Ar flow. The above pretreated samples were then heated to 900 °C with a ramp of 10 °C/min with 5% H2/Ar flow. The H2 consumption signal was analyzed by a TCD. For O2-TPD experiments, about 0.1 g catalyst was pretreated at 300 °C for 1 h with 3% O2/Ar flow, and then cooled to 50 °C under a pure Ar flow. Subsequently, the sample was treated from 50 to 800 °C at a temperature ramp of 10 °C/min in Ar flow. The desorbed O2 species was detected by TCD. For the H2 pulse chemisorption test, 0.1 g samples were pre-reduced for 1 h at 700 °C with 10% H2/Ar flow before dosed with a 5% H2/Ar flow at 50 °C. The actual Rh metal content was investigated with a SPECTROBLUE FMX36 inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). The sulfur content of the used samples was investigated by an Agilent 7700 inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) of the as-prepared catalyst samples was also carried out on a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha with Al Kα radiation, with C 1 s = 284.8 eV as the internal standard to calibrate the binding energy of Rh 3 d and O 1 s. 2.3 Evaluation of catalytic performance A self-built fixed bed quartz tube reactor was used to investigate the catalytic performance of the catalyst samples for diesel reforming. During each test, about 0.1 g of catalyst, diluted with quartz sand (0.1 g), was pre-reduced with a 10% H2/N2 flow for 1 h at 700 °C, and heated to the reaction temperature and then swept for 1 h under a pure N2 flow. The hexadecane and water were each pumped by a high-pressure liquid pump, respectively, into an evaporator that was maintained at 300 °C before hitting the catalyst bed. The molar ratio of steam to fuel was 3:1. The mixed stream was introduced into the fixed bed reactor by a N2 flow to complete the catalytic reforming process. The gas-phase products were condensed, which removes the excess water and unreacted fuel, and then passed through a dryer before entering an on-line gas chromatograph (GC). The obtained dry reformates (including H2, N2, CO, CO2 and CH4 etc.) were then analyzed and quantitated by the TCD and FID detectors in GC. The conversion of diesel is calculated as: Convesion % = n ( C 16 H 34 ) consumed n ( C 16 H 34 ) input × 100 % The carbon balance is calculated as: Carbon balance = n CO + n CO 2 + n CH 4 + 2 n C 2 H 4 + 2 n ( C 2 H 6 ) 16 n ( C 16 H 34 ) The composition of H2, CO, CH4, and CO2 in the products stream is defined as: x % = n i ∑ n i × 100 % Where i refers to the different component in reformate, such as H2, CO, CH4, and CO2 etc. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization To verify the formation of pyrochlore structure in the catalyst samples, wide angle XRD analysis for LaZrRh, Mn-LaZrRh, Fe-LaZrRh and Co-LaZrRh was conducted, and the results are shown in Fig. 1a. As observed, diffraction peaks located at 2θ = 28.3°, 32.6°, 47.0°, 56.1°, 68.9°, 76.1° and 78.6°, corresponding to the (222), (400), (440), (622), (553), (800), and (662) planes of pyrochlore La2Zr2O7 phase (ICSD PDF#73-0444), respectively, were observed for all the prepared catalyst samples [33,40]. In addition, all samples also presented a weak diffraction peak at 31.7°, which could be assigned to the (112) plane of perovskite LaRhO3 phase [41]. The Reference Intensity Ratio (RIR) method was used for the quantitative analysis of pyrochlore and perovskite phase over the prepared TMs-LaZrRh sample, and the corresponding results are shown in Table S1. It can obviously be seen that the percentage of perovskite LaRhO3 phase were below 10% for all the prepared catalysts. Additionally, it is of significance to verify the substitution of B-sites with Rh and TMs ions to ensure they are acceptable in the pyrochlore structure. As shown in Table S2, the ions Rh3+, Mn2+, Fe2+, and Co2+ present a similar ionic radius to Zr4+ with the same VI coordination as Zr4+, but not the same Ⅷ coordination as La3+. Hence, the partial substitution of Zr4+ with Rh3+, Mn2+, Fe2+, and Co2+ in the La2Zr2O7 crystal was well confirmed [42], which was also expected in this work. It is noted that the ionic radius follows the order of Mn2+ > Fe2+ > Co2+ > Zr4+, and the substitution of Zr4+ could result in lattice expansion. In XRD patterns of the prepared samples, an obvious shift in the diffraction peak to lower Bragg values was observed for the TMs-LaZrRh samples (Fig. 1b), which was also accompanied with an increase in the lattice constant and the d-spacing of (222) plane of the TMs-LaZrRh samples when compared to those of the LaZrRh sample ( Table 1). It was suggested that a portion of Zr4+ ions in the pyrochlore La2Zr2O7 might have been substituted by the introduced TMs [33,43]. Raman spectroscopy of the prepared catalyst samples was also performed, and the corresponding spectra are displayed in Fig. 1c. As seen, LaZrRh exhibited a Raman peak at around 299 cm−1, which is associated with the bending vibrations of O-Zr-O in Eg mode, while another peak at around 640 cm−1 was observed, corresponding to the mixed stretching vibrations of La-O and Zr-O, which can be associated with the F2 g mode of Lanthanum Zirconate pyrochlore [44,45]. It was clearly observed that the vibration peaks of the Mn-LaZrRh, Fe-LaZrRh, Co-LaZrRh samples shifted to 629 cm−1, 637 cm−1 and 651 cm−1, respectively, which were lower than that of LaZrRh (i.e. 659 cm−1). This red shift indicated that lattice expansion happened in LaZrRh, which was consistent with the XRD results [46]. The H2-pulse chemisorption was performed to investigate the dispersion of Rh, and the corresponding results are shown in Table 2. Among all samples, Fe-LaZrRh had the highest Rh dispersion of 45.9% and the lowest Rh particle diameter of 3.5 nm. It was reported that catalysts with higher metal dispersion could exhibit better coking and sulfur resistance [47,48]. Thus, it is expected that Fe-LaZrRh would exhibit better tolerance to coking and sulfur poisoning in the reforming process. To find more about the Rh distribution in Fe-LaZrRh, TEM and EDS analysis were used to characterize Rh particle and elemental distribution of Fe-LaZrRh samples, with the corresponding results shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. S1. As seen in Fig. 2a, the sample exhibited an irregular block morphology. The high-resolution TEM image and the inset image (the FFT pattern) exhibited a better crystalline structure, and the different d-spacing values can be assigned to the (222) and (311) planes of La2Zr2O7. Also, after the reduction pretreatment, the Rh species was reduced and existed in the form of a single substance. Fig. 2c shows that the Rh particle size was around 4 nm, and the d-spacing with 0.218 nm was assigned to the (111) plane of Rh. In addition, numerous bright dots were visible in the HADDF-STEM image (Fig. 2d), with an average size smaller than 5 nm, but no bright dots were seen in the HADDF-STEM image of the fresh Fe-LaZrRh sample (Fig. S1a), confirming the reduction of Rh from Rh oxide matrix. From the elemental mapping images (Fig. 2g), the Rh element enriched around the bright dots, but the Rh elemental mapping of the fresh Fe-LaZrRh sample (Fig. S1d) exhibited a uniform distribution of Rh. In addition, as seen in Fig. 2h, a portion of Fe elements also exhibited an enrichment phenomenon around the bright dots, which demonstrates the formation of a Rh-Fe bimetallic catalyst. Also, the La, Zr and O elemental images (Fig. 2e, f, i) were distributed uniformly, while the EDS accurate analysis on a HADDF-STEM mode (Fig. S2) showed that the weight ratio of Rh was 2.52%. Finally, the actual Rh content, calculated by ICP-OES, is displayed in Table 2. As seen from the table, the actual Rh contents were a little larger than its theoretical values. The H2-TPR of the prepared catalysts and its Gaussian-fitting profiles are displayed in Fig. 3, Fig. S3 and Table S3. As seen, all catalysts presented three reduction peaks (Fig. 3), which were attributed to the reduction of RhOx under different chemical environments. And the low-temperature reduction peaks for all samples can be attributed to the reduction of Rh2O3 specie on the surface of catalyst ( Rh 3 + + 3 e − → R h 0 ) [28]. The two high-temperature reduction peaks were most likely assigned to the Rh-O species coordinated with oxygen atoms within the perovskite and pyrochlore structure, confirming that a portion of Rh was located in the lattice structure [33,49]. However, the reduction temperature of Fe-LaZrRh and Mn-LaZrRh, especially for the Fe-LaZrRh sample, shifted to a higher temperature, indicating the existence of a synergistic interaction between Rh and Fe, which further resulted in a stronger metal-La2Zr2O7 interaction. The strong interactions between the metal and the support enhanced the dispersion of active metals and decreased the size of active metals [24,50]. Moreover, the results of Gaussian-fitting showed that the concentration of Rh2O3 species exposed on the surface of catalysts followed the sequence of Co-LaZrRh (92.7%) > LaZrRh (50.8%) > Mn-LaZrRh (3%) > Fe-LaZrRh (1.2%) (Table S3). This result demonstrated that all the Rh was basically anchored at Zr-sites of the Fe-LaZrRh samples. Additionally, the highest dispersion of Rh and the smallest Rh diameter in Fe-LaZrRh, characterized by H2-pluse chemisorption, may further support this conclusion (Table 1). The XRD patterns of the reduced catalyst samples are shown in Fig. 1d. As seen, the reduced catalysts still presented a Lanthanum Zirconate pyrochlore structure. However, the diffraction peak assigned to LaRhO3 perovskite disappeared for all samples, which is possibly due to the reduction of Rh species to Rh metal and the subsequent breakup of the LaRhO3 perovskite structure. Additionally, no diffraction peak assigned to the metal phase was observed for the reduced samples, which might be attributed to the low metal content and/or high dispersion of metal particles [14]. 3.2 Catalytic performance In general, sulfur poisoning is the main reason of catalyst deactivation during the reforming process. This is because the presence of sulfur can not only adsorb onto the active metal sites, but also impede the gasification of carbon and accelerate graphitic carbon formation, thus resulting in catalyst deactivation due to carbon deposition and sulfur poisoning [24]. The sulfur tolerance performance of the prepared samples is displayed in Fig. 4 (The data points are the averages of three replicate runs with a maximum error less than 5%, which are the same for the rest of figures). As seen, all the prepared catalysts presented a good catalytic activity for n-hexadecane reforming during the 10 h run. However, different catalyst samples displayed different activities in hydrogen extraction. For LaZrRh, the average H2 composition in reformate was 67.3% when no sulfur present, but it decreased significantly to 62.4% in the presence of organic sulfur. In addition, the decrease in H2 composition was accompanied by an obvious increase in CO concentration, which could be attributed to that the presence of DBT accelerated carbon deposition, and the deposited carbon on catalyst surface would lead to carbon dissolution ( CO 2 + C ⇋ 2 CO ) [50,51]. This was reflected with an increase in CO concentration and a decrease in CO2 concentration. For the TMs-LaZrRh samples, especially for Fe-LaZrRh and Mn-LaZrRh, a significantly enhanced hydrogen extraction capability was observed due to the improved sulfur tolerance. Specifically, Fe-LaZrRh samples exhibited the best catalytic performance with an average H2 composition of 70.4% in the absence of sulfur, which is very close to its theoretical value of 71% (from Aspen Plus simulation). It is also noted that there was only trace amount of CH4 (0.2%) in the reformate. However, when 50 ppm DBT was introduced into the feed, the average H2 composition was reduced to 68.7% for Fe-LaZrRh, which was still higher than that of LaZrRh. At the same time, the average H2 composition for Mn-LaZrRh was 65.7% in the presence of sulfur. For Co-LaZrRh, the partial substitution of Co presented a negative impact on the hydrogen extraction capability and sulfur tolerance, with an average H2 composition of only 66.5% and 61.2% in the absence and presence of sulfur, respectively. The adsorbed sulfur content on the used catalysts was also studied with ICP-MS, and the corresponding data is listed in Fig. 5. As observed, the Fe-LaZrRh catalyst had the lowest sulfur content (0.011%) on its surface after use, and this result demonstrated that Fe-LaZrRh had an excellent property in suppressing sulfur adsorbed on the Rh particles. In addition, the pyrochlore structures were kept intact for all of the spent catalysts as indicated by their XRD patterns (Fig. S4). Moreover, the carbon balance for the TMs-LaZrRh samples with 0 ppm S and 50 ppm S was calculated and checked, and the results are listed in Table S4. As seen, the carbon balance was 0.91–0.96 (a little below 1.0,) which is actually not bad. The little deviation from 1.0, we think, might be due to the coke deposited on the quartz tube or the catalyst bed, which had not been included in the reformate. In reforming of liquid hydrocarbons, the longer the carbon chain of the fuel treated, the higher the reaction temperature required. Generally, the steam reforming temperature for hexadecane requres above 800 °C, on the other hand, a lower temperature can accelerate the deposition of carbon on the catalyst [52]. However, considering the energy consumption, there is a strong need for catalysts that have better hexadecane reforming performance at lower temperatures. Hence, the catalytic steam reforming performance for the Fe-LaZrRh catalyst in the temperature range of 750–850 °C was investigated, and the experimental results are shown in Fig. 6. As seen, with the decrease of temperature, the fuel conversion remained unchanged (∼99.6%), while a slight change was observed for the composition of the reformates. The average of H2 and CH4 composition after 10 h at 850 °C, 800 °C, 750 °C was 68.7%, 68.0%, 66.6% and 0.9%, 1.9%, 2.6%, respectively. The H2 composition only had a slight decrease accompanied by the decreased of temperature. Moreover, it can be seen the CO concentration gradually decreased, while CO2 production gradually increased with the decrease in temperature. Fig. 7a shows the stability of Fe-LaZrRh in the presence 50 ppm sulfur at 850 °C. As seen, Fe-LaZrRh sample exhibited an excellent stability for 70 h run. The dotted lines represent the theoretical composition (obtained from Aspen simulation) of reformate at the same conditions, and the theoretical value for H2, CO, CH4, and CO2 is 71.0%, 18.0%, 0.0%, and 11.0%, respectively. At the same time, the measured actual composition of H2, CO, CH4, and CO2 was 68.6%, 19.3%, 0.9%, and 11.2% (they are the average values of 70 h run), respectively, which is very close to their theoretical values. The above results demonstrated that Fe-LaZrRh had the highest catalytic performance, the greatest sulfur resistance and thermal stability in hexadecane reforming. The XPS was used to characterize the adsorbed carbon species for the spent Fe-LaZrRh catalysts, and the corresponding C 1 s profiles are shown in Fig. 7b. As seen, the adsorbed carbon species for the used Fe-LaZrRh sample were C-C, C-H, and O-CO bond, respectively [53]. And the C-C (41.2%) and C-H (47.1%) bonds were the main adsorbed carbon species, which can effectively be broken by Rh active metal. For comparison, some previously reported Rh-based catalysts used for n-hexadecane reforming were summarized and compared with the catalyst prepared in this study, and the results are listed in Table S5. The catalytic performance of the Fe-LaZrRh catalyst was much better than those reported in literature, and it also had a better long-term stability in the presence of 50 ppm sulfur. 3.3 Surface chemical environment It was reported that it is hard for sulfur to withdraw electrons from electron-deficient active metal, which could result in a weak interaction between sulfur and the metal; thus leading to a high sulfur resistance for reforming catalysts [54]. In this work, XPS was carried out to monitor the electronic structure of Rh and oxygen species in the prepared catalyst samples. And Fig. 8a is the Rh 3d XPS spectra of the four fresh catalyst samples. As observed, all samples presented two asymmetric peaks around 308.9 eV and 313.6 eV, which had well separated spin-orbit components (Δ = 4.7 eV), suggesting the presence of a Rh3+ oxide matrix [33,55]. Additionally, compared to LaZrRh, the shift of banding energy (B.E.) was observed with the addition of transition metals, suggesting the modification of the electronic structure of Rh species. Among all samples prepared, Fe-LaZrRh showed the highest B.E. (309.4 eV), which demonstrated the decrease of electron cloud density around Rh, and the results indicated that electron-deficient Rh sites were generated on the Fe-LaZrRh. The existence of electron-deficient Rh sites could hinder sulfur’s adsorbing of metals to generate an irreversible sulfur-metal bond, and thus resulted in a better resistance to sulfur poisoning. Moreover, the catalytic activity of Fe-LaZrRh confirmed its excellent sulfur tolerance, that is, the XPS results and catalytic performance could be mutually verified. As further seen, the XPS spectra of O 1 s in Fig. 8b was fitted into two peaks. The peak centered at around 528.9 eV was ascribed to the bulk lattice oxygen in the La2Zr2O7 pyrochlore structure, named as “β-O2”, while the peak located at 531.3 eV was the characteristic peak of the surface adsorbed oxygen species (e.g., O2-, O 2 2 − , OH- or O-), named as “α-O2” [56–58]. For the reforming reaction, surface oxygen species have also a pronounced effect on the catalytic reforming activity, which can facilitate the carbon oxidation to remove carbon deposition [24]. Shown in Table 3 are the Ro (α-O2/β-O2) values. As seen, the Ro value of the fresh Fe-LaZrRh was the highest (1.21) compared to other fresh samples. Moreover, the O2-TPD experiment was also investigated to verify the existence of oxygen species in the fresh TMs-LaZrRh catalyst samples, and the corresponding profiles are shown in Fig. 9. As seen, a notable desorption peak occurred at 300–550 °C for all the TMs-LaZrRh samples, which can be assigned to the surface adsorbed oxygen species [59]. Specifically, the peak of Fe-LaZrRh was broader and higher than those of other samples. In summary, the above results verified that it is the introduction of Fe that resulted in the formation of more oxygen vacancies. Fig. 8c shows the Rh 3d XPS spectra of Fe-LaZrRh-fresh, Fe-LaZrRh-reduced, and Fe-LaZrRh-used samples. As seen, the Rh 3d spectra of Fe-LaZrRh-reduced, and Fe-LaZrRh-used samples were divided into four peaks. The peaks centered at 307.1 eV and 311.8 eV were assigned to the metallic Rh [9,55,60], and the peaks located at 308.9 eV and 313.6 eV were assigned to Rh3+ species. According to the H2-TPR profile of Fe-LaZrRh, the part of RhOx species can be reduced into metallic Rh when below 700 °C (pre-reduced temperature), and some Rh under the coordination environment could kept the state of RhOx. Thus, the metallic Rh and Rh3+ coexist on the Fe-LaZrRh-reduced and Fe-LaZrRh-used samples. Shown in Fig. 8d are the O 1 s XPS spectra of Fe-LaZrRh-fresh, Fe-LaZrRh-reduced, and Fe-LaZrRh-used samples. As seen, all spectra can be divided into two peaks corresponding to β-O2 species and α-O2 species. However, from Table 3, the Ro of the Fe-LaZrRh-reduced (2.75) was much larger than that of Fe-LaZrRh-fresh (1.21), which might be due to the metallic Rh reduced from the pyrochlore structure. These would result in the generation of defects sites, which further contributed to the migration of oxygen. At the same time, the Ro of the Fe-LaZrRh-used slightly decreased. 3.4 Cyclic performance Cyclability is another essential index for evaluating catalyst performance. In fact, carbon deposited on the used catalyst (which caused the catalyst deactivation) can be removed through oxygen calcination [61]. In view of this, harsher temperatures (800 °C) and higher organic sulfur content (100 ppm) were applied to accelerate the deactivation of catalysts to study the regenerative and cyclic capability of Fe-LaZrRh. For this purpose, the used Fe-LaZrRh sample was treated at 800 ℃ and atmospheric pressure for 2 h to achieve regeneration and reuse three times. The results are shown in Fig. 10. As obviously seen, the fuel conversion and composition of reformates for the regenerated samples were approximately the same as those of the fresh samples, indicating that Fe-LaZrRh catalyst had a good recyclability. 3.5 Mechanism study The mechanism of diesel steam reforming is very complex, which may include many parallel reactions, such as dehydrogenation, alkyl elimination, and pyrolysis etc. Therefore, it is usually hard to obtain the reaction mechanism of diesel reforming. Nevertheless, an investigation for the reaction mechanism was still performed in this work, as it is one of our major tasks. It is believed that the study can be greatly simplified when long-chain alkanes were used as the model compound to represent diesel. Indeed, over the past several decades, many researchers had been doing it the same way. For instance, Xue et al. [1] studied the mechanism in steam reforming of n-dodecane, and they figured out the adsorption energies of the intermediates generated in the main reaction using the DFT calculation. Inspired by their work, a plausible mechanism for the n-hexadecane steam reforming was proposed in this work (see Fig. 11). The mechanism, we believe, may include the following several steps: First, the hydrocarbons were adsorbed on Rh active sites forming alkyl and hydrogen radicals as a result of dehydrogenation reaction (Eq. 2). Secondly, the steam was activated by the oxygen vacancies leading to the formation of active oxygen species (O*) (Eq. 3). Finally, plenty of methylene radicals ( CH 2 * ) were generated due to the breaking of C-H bonds, and the CH 2 * would generate H2 and carbon oxides (CO or CO2) through further dehydrogenation and oxygenation process (Eqs. 4 and 5). (2) n − hexadecane + * → R → CH 3 + H * → CH 2 * + H * (3) H 2 O + oxygen vacancies → H * + O * (4) CH 2 * + O * → CO + 2 H * (5) H * + H * → H 2 + 2 * Since the introduction of Fe could significantly improve the catalytic performance, the above mechanism must have something to do with the following reasons: (1) The significantly improved Rh-La2Zr2O7 interaction would result in higher Rh dispersion and smaller size of Rh particles. Thus, more active sites were exposed on the surface of catalysts and available for the adsorption of reactive species to enhance catalytic activity. (2) The changed electronic state of Rh, that is, the formation of electron-deficient Rh sites (which was verified by the XPS) would make it hard for sulfur to withdraw electrons from Rh to generate the irreversible Rh-S bond, and thus significantly improving the tolerance to sulfur poisoning. (3) The mixed valences of Fe species could enhance the concentration of oxygen vacancies, which can further facilitate the generation of active oxygen species by activating the steam. Therefore, the deposited carbon could be efficiently removed during the reforming process. 4 Conclusion A series of transition metals (such as Co, Fe, and Mn etc.) promoted Rh-based catalysts were synthesized and used in reforming hexadecane for H2 production. The variation of operation conditions such as with or without sulfur existence on catalytic activity in diesel reforming was studied. Characterizations of the catalysts with XRD and Raman showed that both TMs and Rh were successfully implemented in the pyrochlore structure, and the B-sites (Zr) of La2Zr2O7 were indeed partially substituted by TMs. It was found that the introduction of Fe could effectively enhance the interactions between Rh and La2Zr2O7, and this had resulted in the enhancement of Rh dispersion and the decrease of Rh particle size. Among all the samples prepared and studied, the catalyst Fe-LaZrRh exhibited the highest Rh dispersion of 45.6% and smallest Rh particle size of 3.5 nm, which could be the reason leading to the excellent capability in suppressing carbon deposition and sulfur poisoning. Moreover, the investigation of catalytic performance further indicated that the Fe-LaZrRh catalyst generated the highest H2 concentration in the reformate, and the catalyst had the best thermal stability during the over 70 h run under the existence of 50 ppm organic sulfur. The XPS results further verified that the introduction of Fe facilitated the formation of electron-deficient Rh sites and the generation of oxygen vacancies, which might be the main reason that suppress the formation of the irreversible sulfur-metal bond, and help the gasification of the deposited carbon and sulfur. Additionally, the stability tests indicated that Fe-LaZrRh catalyst had almost no degradation after three cyclic runs under harsh conditions, potentially making it a good candidate for serving as the catalyst in diesel reforming. More work on the catalyst life and the optimization of reforming conditions is needed. CRediT authorship contribution statement Wang Duo: Resources. coredata.dc:description: Several Rh-based La2Zr2O7 type catalysts promoted by the transition metals (Mn, Fe, and Co respectively) were synthesized and used to reform n-hexadecane (a diesel surrogate) that contains 50 ppm dibenzothiophene for hydrogen production. Compared to Co-LaZrRh and Mn-LaZrRh, the Fe-LaZrRh catalyst exhibited the best hydrogen extraction capability and sulfur tolerance. This is probably due to the introduction of Fe, which not only enhances the Rh dispersion, but also facilitates the formation of electron-deficient Rh sites and the generation of oxygen vacancies. Additionally, electron-deficient Rh sites can hinder the formation of an irreversible sulfur-metal bond, thus resulting in better sulfur tolerance and thermal stability. Finally, the generated oxygen vacancies may also activate steam to form surface active oxygen species, which help remove the deposited carbon on the catalyst surface. In summary, the developed Fe-LaZrRh catalyst performed the best in the steam reforming of n-hexadecane containing 50 ppm sulfur, which deserves further exploration for future applications.
coredata.dc:title: Promotion of Rh-based La2Zr2O7 type catalysts with the transition metals to improve sulfur-tolerance in diesel reforming
